results.title: Properties of matter
results.creator_credit: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Physical science in action”.
Matter is anything and everything that takes up space. This program investigates the different properties of matter - mass, weight, volume and density, as well as the four phases of matter - solid, liquid, gas and plasma. Also introduced is the idea of chemical properties to further help describe and understand the world we live in. Suitable for Upper primary/lower secondary students. Teachers notes included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media

results.title: Forces
results.creator_credit: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Physical science in action”.
There are many forces at work shaping our world every moment of our lives. This video describes Newton’s laws (first, second and third), friction, gravity, air and water pressure, and electromagnetism. Also explored is the concept of unbalanced forces. Suitable for Upper primary/lower secondary students. Teachers notes included.

results.title: Photography: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Coast Telecourses USA, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Hollander
results.brief_description: This series forms part of an Open Learning Unit offered by RMIT. It presents the technical principles of photography, the mechanics of the camera, the chemicals and physical reactions which produce a permanent image, the uses of various kinds of photographic equipment and techniques for producing better quality photographs.

results.title: Photography in science
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Overviews the wide variety of applications for scientific photography from providing legal evidence to diagnosing diseases. It is used to document, measure, reveal and communicate. Advances in computer and digital technology are revolutionising scientific photography and some of these changes are explained.

results.title: Studio and Location
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Profiles three Australian photographers - Jacqui Henshaw, Adrian Van Valen and John Gollings. Concentrating on fashion, architectural and car photography, they discuss the differences between shooting on location and in the studio with each context having its own advantages and limitations.

results.title: Photography around us
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Offers an introduction to the history of photography in Australia and its gradual acceptance as an artform by museums and educational institutions. Local authorities in the field discuss changing attitudes to photography. In particular Sue Fereday, Director of the Centre for Contemporary Photography, and Isobel Crombie, Curator of Photography at the National Gallery of Victoria explain their policies towards collecting and exhibiting photography.

results.title: Phoenix. Eps. 25-26
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mark Callan, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Phoenix”.
The final episodes of the television series “Phoenix”. Snow Job’: Chris is dealing with Sergio, her drug contact, and organises to buy 90% pure cocaine which indicates the drugs are probably off the boat. The Federal Police plant a camera on the boat to monitor activity but make mistakes in doing so. They send in two undercover cops to act as Customs agents but the crew realise there’s rat on board, resulting in dire consequences for Peter’s informant. Now that Peter does not have an informant on the ship, it is up to Chris to lead the squads to the drugs.Hit, Shit and Scatter’: Due to the continual mistakes made by the Major’s, a crisis meeting is called to discuss their future and they realise they will have to go after the crooks before the unit ceases to exist. Flannagan delivers drugs to Sergio in a hotel and they have enough evidence on him to charge him with intent, plus murder, thanks to the phone tap at the Food Plus store. Murdoch is brought in to tell the squad some devastating new about their future.

results.title: Phoenix. Eps. 23-24
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Julian McSwiney, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Phoenix”.
Shuffling Deck’: Now that the case has intensified from aggravated burglary to drug importation, the Federal Police are brought in and want to take over the investigation. There is no way the Majors will allow this to happen, so they decide to work together as a joint task force to try and catch the crooks. Ian and the forensics team has a breakthrough in the identity of Betty’s rapist with the discovery of very high lead levels in his blood.Under Siege’: Victor Flannagan is seen at a market talking to another character whom the Majors follow. He turns out to be Gary McKinnon and the Majors think he may be one of the burglars. They keep a trace on Gary’s flat and end up with enough evidence for a raid. It eventuates that Gary’s flat is rented out under the same name of the stolen Medicare card that was used to sell James Arthur’s Rolex to the pawn shop. The raid does not go well; firstly, they have trouble breaking the door down, then they lose Gary who escapes out a window, his terrified girlfriend also jumps out of a window and may never walk again. All the squad members are interviewed over the ensuing investigation into whether someone pushed her, which brings bad light on the Major crime Squad, again. Peter tracks Gary down to his ex-girlfriends house where he is taken hostage in a very violent situation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kate Woods, Julian McSwiney, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Phoenix. Eps. 21-22
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mark Callan, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Phoenix”.
Episodes 21 and 22 of the television series Phoenix. In On The Joke’: IID are focusing on Peter as he has had $20,000 go into his bank account which is unaccounted for, consequently he becomes the target of an investigation, especially after Internal Affairs hear him make a deal with an informant. Stanley - a not so trusted informant - gives the Majors information about the stolen jewelry, that it is being melted down into gold blocks to make it easier to handle. Stanley gives them the name Victor Flannagan as the head leader of this racket, but not before giving the Majors a chase across the states where he is wanted for all sorts of offences.Give A Dog A Bone’: Now that the squad has a name, they have to start their own surveillance as the toe cutters upstairs have reduced their surveillance services to the squad. They discover Flannagan is using the phone at a Food Plus store to discuss his criminal activities and they are going to have to tap the phone to try and find out about a huge drug importation coming in, luckily Peter has an informant at the wharf to help them with their investigation.

In On The Joke’: IID are focusing on Peter as he has had $20,000 go into his bank account which is unaccounted for, consequently he becomes the target of an investigation, especially after Internal Affairs hear him make a deal with an informant. Stanley - a not so trusted informant - gives the Majors information about the stolen jewelry, that it is being melted down into gold blocks to make it easier to handle. Stanley gives them the name Victor Flannagan as the head leader of this racket, but not before giving the Majors a chase across the states where he is wanted for all sorts of offences.Give A Dog A Bone’: Now that the squad has a name, they have to start their own surveillance as the toe cutters upstairs have reduced their surveillance services to the squad. They discover Flannagan is using the phone at a Food Plus store to discuss his criminal activities and they are going to have to tap the phone to try and find out about a huge drug importation coming in, luckily Peter has an informant at the wharf to help them with their investigation.
description_for_label:
Episode number 11 of Series “Phoenix”.
Episodes 21 and 22 of the television series Phoenix. In On The Joke’: IID are focusing on Peter as he has had $20,000 go into his bank account which is unaccounted for, consequently he becomes the target of an investigation, especially after Internal Affairs hear him make a deal with an informant. Stanley - a not so trusted informant - gives the Majors information about the stolen jewelry, that it is being melted down into gold blocks to make it easier to handle. Stanley gives them the name Victor Flannagan as the head leader of this racket, but not before giving the Majors a chase across the states where he is wanted for all sorts of offences.Give A Dog A Bone’: Now that the squad has a name, they have to start their own surveillance as the toe cutters upstairs have reduced their surveillance services to the squad. They discover Flannagan is using the phone at a Food Plus store to discuss his criminal activities and they are going to have to tap the phone to try and find out about a huge drug importation coming in, luckily Peter has an informant at the wharf to help them with their investigation.
